data.title: Film Screening and Discussion with Theodore Bikel and Leonard Maltin: "Theodore Bikel: In the Shoes of Sholom Aleichem"
data.meta_description: Portraits of two beloved icons - Sholom Aleichem and Theodore Bikel - are woven together in the enchanting new documentary, "Theodore Bikel: In the Shoes of Sholom Aleichem" that reveals the wit, wisdom and talent the two men share.
data.meta_site_name: LAist - NPR News for Southern California - 89.3 FM
data.text:
Portraits of two beloved icons - Sholom Aleichem and Theodore Bikel - are woven together in the enchanting new documentary, "Theodore Bikel: In the Shoes of Sholom Aleichem" that reveals the wit, wisdom and talent the two men share. Bikel, the unstoppable performer whose career spans more than 150 screen roles and countless stage and musical productions, is also the foremost interpreter of Sholom Aleichem's work, having portrayed the beloved Tevye the Milkman on stage more than 2,000 times.

Sholom Aleichem, a masterful pioneer of modern Jewish literature who championed and luxuriated in the Yiddish language, continues to provide us with an invaluable window into pre-war Eastern European Jewish life, real and imagined.

You can join for this entertaining portrait to hear directly from Theodore Bikel, who will introduce the film and engage in a Q&A with film critic and historian Leonard Maltin.

Event Info:

Sunday, May 3

4:00 PM

Tickets from $30

Reception with Theodore Bikel following the discussion, includes Preferred seating (Row D): $65

About the sponsor:

The Whizin Center for Continuing Education (WCCE) is dedicated to life-long learning. Their multidisciplinary program features a wide variety of courses that make for meaningful personal experiences which can lead to new insights into the world and the community. A variety of courses in Jewish studies, Hebrew language, the arts and personal growth are offered, in addition to special seminars, all-day institutes, public lectures and residential study experiences. WCCE endeavors to enrich all aspects of Jewish life – the cultural and intellectual, the artistic and religious, the political and social – to ensure the creative continuity of the Jewish people.

The WCCE distinguished faculty includes scholars and noted specialists at American Jewish University, as well as experts in their field from around the country.
